title: War of the Euboeote Succession
text:
The War of the Euboeote Succession was fought in 1256–1258 between the <a href="Principality%20of%20Achaea">Prince of Achaea</a>, <a href="William%20II%20of%20Villehardouin">William II of Villehardouin</a>, and a broad coalition of other rulers from throughout <a href="Frankish%20Greece">Frankish Greece</a> who felt threatened by William's aspirations. The war was sparked by William's attempt to gain control of a third of the island of <a href="Euboea">Euboea</a>, which was resisted by the local <a href="Lombards">Lombard</a> barons ("terciers" or "triarchs") with the aid of the <a href="Republic%20of%20Venice">Republic of Venice</a>. The <a href="Duchy%20of%20Athens">Lord of Athens and Thebes</a>, <a href="Guy%20I%20de%20la%20Roche">Guy I de la Roche</a>, also entered the war against William, along with other barons of <a href="Central%20Greece">Central Greece</a>. Their defeat at the Battle of Karydi in May/June 1258 effectively brought the war to an end in an Achaean victory, although a definite peace treaty was not concluded until 1262.
Background.
Following the <a href="Fourth%20Crusade">Fourth Crusade</a>, southern <a href="Greece">Greece</a> had been divided among several <a href="Latinokratia">Latin</a> lordships, the most powerful of which was the <a href="Principality%20of%20Achaea">Principality of Achaea</a>, which controlled the entire <a href="Peloponnese">Peloponnese</a> peninsula. <a href="William%20II%20of%20Villehardouin">William II of Villehardouin</a>, who in 1246 had succeeded his elder brother as prince, was a most energetic ruler, who aimed to expand and consolidate his rule over the other Latin states. <a href="Guy%20I%20de%20la%20Roche">Guy I de la Roche</a>, the "Great Lord" of Athens and Thebes, was already his vassal for the <a href="fief">fief</a> of <a href="Argos%20and%20Nauplia">Argos and Nauplia</a>, which lay in the Peloponnese, and William was also <a href="suzerain">suzerain</a> of the three Lombard baronies ("<a href="terziere">terzieri</a>", "thirds") of <a href="Triarchy%20of%20Negroponte">Negroponte</a> (the medieval name of both the island of <a href="Euboea">Euboea</a> and its capital, modern <a href="Chalkis">Chalkis</a>).
In 1255, William's second wife, <a href="Carintana%20dalle%20Carceri">Carintana dalle Carceri</a>, baroness of the northern third of the island, died, and her husband laid claim to her inheritance, even minting coins presenting himself as "Triarch of Negroponte". The other two triarchs, however, <a href="William%20I%20of%20Verona">Guglielmo of Verona</a> and <a href="Narzotto%20dalle%20Carceri">Narzotto dalle Carceri</a>, rejected his claim. Although they were William's nominal subjects and, in Guglielmo's case, even related to him by marriage, they were loath to surrender Euboeote territory to someone outside their own families. Instead, they ceded Carintana's barony to their kinsman, Grapella dalle Carceri. In this, they were supported by Paolo Gradenigo, the <a href="Republic%20of%20Venice">Venetian</a> "<a href="Bailo%20of%20Negroponte">bailo</a>" (representative) at Negroponte, the capital of Euboea. Venice had a long presence at Negroponte, which was an important trading station, and exercised considerable influence over the island and the triarchs.
Formation of the anti-Achaean alliance.
According to the historian <a href="Marino%20Sanuto%20the%20Elder">Marino Sanudo</a>, Villehardouin called upon Guglielmo and Narzotto to present themselves to him. Constrained by their feudal oaths of <a href="fealty">fealty</a>, they did so and were imprisoned by the Achaean prince. The triarchs' wives, accompanied by many <a href="knight">knight</a>s and other kinsmen, then went to the Venetian "bailo", and beseeched his aid. "Moved alike by policy and sympathy", as the historian William Miller states, Paolo Gradenigo assented. Sanudo portrays this as the origin of the Venetian assistance to the triarchs, and claims that the triarchs remained imprisoned until after Villehardouin himself was captured at <a href="Battle%20of%20Pelagonia">Pelagonia</a> in 1259, but this may in fact reflect a brief imprisonment, since the two triarchs were clearly at liberty in June 1256 and January 1257.
On 14 June 1256, a treaty was signed between the Lombard triarchs and Gradenigo at Thebes, the chief residence of Guy I de la Roche. The triarchs repudiated their vassalage to Achaea and declared themselves lieges of the <a href="Commune%20of%20Venice">Commune of Venice</a>, as token of which they would send an annual gift of cloths of gold to Venice, one each for the Doge and <a href="St%20Mark%27s%20Basilica">St. Mark's Cathedral</a>, and hold festive liturgies in Venice's honour at Christmas, Easter, and the feast-day of St. Mark. The previous agreements of 1209 and 1216 were renewed, but, while the triarchs and their domains were freed from any duties and the considerable tribute that they paid to Venice until then, they in turn gave up the rights to all customs revenue to the Republic. Venice also received further concessions, such as the right to regulate the weights, measures and scales for all Euboea, and privileges for its citizens. More importantly, the triarchs ceded to the Republic full possession of the strategic citadel that guarded the bridge over the <a href="Euripus%20Strait">Euripus Strait</a>, and of extensive properties in the city of Negroponte itself. This marked the establishment of a separate Venetian colony in Negroponte, and began the long and gradual process whereby the entirety of the city and island of Negroponte would pass under Venetian rule. 
Faced with the opposition of Venice, Villehardouin turned to her rival, <a href="Republic%20of%20Genoa">Genoa</a>, for support. The Genoese, ever eager to thwart the Venetians, and owing a debt for Villehardouin's assistance to them <a href="Genoese%20occupation%20of%20Rhodes">at Rhodes</a> a few years before, readily accepted. Based at <a href="Monemvasia">Monemvasia</a>, Genoese-crewed galleys preyed upon Venetian shipping. <a href="Othon%20de%20Cicon">Othon de Cicon</a>, the lord of <a href="Karystos">Karystos</a> in southern Euboea, in control of the strategic passage of the <a href="Cavo%20D%27Oro">Cavo D'Oro</a>, also sided with Villehardouin. Elsewhere, however, Villehardouin's appeals were met with hostility and mistrust, due to the Achaean ruler's claims of suzerainty over all the Latin princes of southern Greece. From the summer of 1256, Guy I de la Roche and his kinsman <a href="William%20de%20la%20Roche%20%28lord%20of%20Veligosti%29">William de la Roche</a>, had joined the Venetian camp, although they were both vassals to the Villehardouins (Guy as Lord of Argos and Nauplia and his brother as <a href="Barony%20of%20Veligosti">baron of Veligosti and Damala</a>). They were joined by the <a href="Lord%20of%20Salona">Lord of Salona</a>, <a href="Thomas%20II%20d%27Autremencourt">Thomas II d'Autremencourt</a>, and <a href="Ubertino%20Pallavicini">Ubertino Pallavicini</a>, <a href="Marquis%20of%20Bodonitsa">Marquis of Bodonitsa</a>. 
In October 1256, a new "bailo", Marco Gradenigo, was sent to Negroponte with three <a href="galley">galley</a>s (seven, according to <a href="Andrea%20Dandolo">Andrea Dandolo</a>) and full authority to deal with the triarchs as he saw fit. On 25 January 1257 Gradenigo and the triarchs concluded a full alliance against Villehardouin, with both sides undertaking not to conclude a separate peace without consulting the other.
Contest for Negroponte.
Already in 1256, Villehardouin, moving quickly in support of his own claims, seized Negroponte, only for the city to be recovered by the Venetians under Paolo Gradenigo. Villehardouin responded by sending his nephew, the <a href="baron%20of%20Karytaina">baron of Karytaina</a>, <a href="Geoffroy%20of%20Briel">Geoffroy of Briel</a>, who recaptured Negroponte and launched devastating raids in Euboea. 
After arriving in Greece, Marco Gradenigo laid siege to the city, which dragged on for thirteen months. The assistance of the de la Roche brothers proved critical in forcing its capitulation in early 1258. An Achaean counterattack was repulsed by Venetian pike-wielding infantry sallying forth and defeating the famed Achaean cavalry before the city's walls. At some point, the anti-Achaean league was also joined by Geoffrey of Briel, deemed "the best soldier in all the realm of Romania [i.e. Latin Greece]", who deserted his uncle's cause.
Battle of Karydi and the end of the war.
William of Villehardouin responded by what <a href="William%20Miller%20%28historian%29">William Miller</a> described as "restless activity": he unsuccessfully besieged the Venetian fortress of <a href="Koroni">Coron</a>, and led a raid into <a href="Attica">Attica</a>, where he was nearly captured, before resolving on launching a full-scale invasion of the de la Roche domains. His army assembled at <a href="Nikli">Nikli</a>, crossed the <a href="Isthmus%20of%20Corinth">Isthmus of Corinth</a>, and at the pass of Mount Karydi, on the way from <a href="Megara">Megara</a> to Thebes, his army decisively defeated the coalition army. Guy de la Roche and the other barons fled the field and found refuge in the citadel of Thebes. William of Villehardouin followed after them and prepared to lay siege to the city, but relented after the <a href="Latin%20Archbishop%20of%20Thebes">Latin archbishop</a> and many of his own nobles pleaded to show restraint and end the conflict. After extracting a pledge by Guy de la Roche to appear before the Achaean High Court, the assembly of the Achaean barons, and be judged, William's troops withdrew.
The High Court quickly assembled at Nikli. Guy de la Roche presented himself before it accompanied by his own knights, but the assembled barons decided that they did not have the authority to judge him, and referred the matter to King <a href="Louis%20IX%20of%20France">Louis IX of France</a> (). Guy travelled to <a href="France">France</a> in 1259, but Louis not only pardoned him, but awarded him the title of <a href="Duke">Duke</a>, which he and his successors were to bear thereafter. The renegade Geoffroy of Briel too was brought for judgement before William, and it was only the determined and passionate intercession of the other barons that saved his life and secured a pardon from the vengeful prince. He was however deprived of the possession of his domains by the inalienable right of conquest, and retained them henceforth as a gift from the Prince, meaning that they would be forfeit upon his death unless he had any immediate descendants.
Aftermath.
William's victory at Karydi, coupled with a victory of his troops against the Venetians near <a href="Oreoi">Oreoi</a>, brought an effective end to the conflict; on 6 August 1258, Guglielmo da Verona and Narzotto dalle Carceri consented to begin negotiations for peace through the <a href="Doge%20of%20Venice">Doge of Venice</a>, and in early 1259, the Doge authorized the new "bailo", <a href="Andrea%20Barozzi">Andrea Barozzi</a>, to sign a treaty with William. But due to William's subsequent involvement in the great <a href="Despotate%20of%20Epirus">Epirote</a>-Achaean-<a href="Kingdom%20of%20Sicily">Sicilian</a> alliance against the <a href="Empire%20of%20Nicaea">Empire of Nicaea</a>, his defeat and capture at Pelagonia and his captivity at the hands of the Byzantine emperor <a href="Michael%20VIII%20Palaiologos">Michael VIII Palaiologos</a> (), a final peace treaty was delayed until William's release in 1262. 
The treaty, signed at the residence of the Archbishop of Thebes, essentially restored the "<a href="status%20quo">status quo ante</a>": William recognized Guglielmo, Narzotto, and Grapella as triarchs, and they in turn swore their allegiance to him. The fortress of Negroponte was razed, but Venice retained and even increased its quarter in the city, as well as retaining its exclusive right to levy customs in Euboea, except for the triarchs, the Prince, and their agents. Thus, Venice retained some of its 1256 gains, but overall the treaty was regarded as a setback, in view of the considerable expenses incurred. For some time afterwards, Venice was content to exercise her financial privileges, and refrained from meddling with the island's politics.
